Authors:
Asha Janadaree Dissanayake, Wei Zhang, Mei Liu, QiKai Xing,
Zhen Chen, Kevin D Hyde, JiYe Yan, XingHong Li
Title:
Diaporthe species causing gummosis of Prunus persica in China
with descriptions of four new species
Keywords:
Morphology, Multi-gene phylogeny, Pathogenicity, Peach,
Taxonomy
Abstract:
Species of Diaporthe are important plant pathogens on a
wide range of host plants worldwide. In this study, Diaporthe species
causing gummosis of Prunus persica in Jinshui Experimental Orchard of
Hubei Academy of Agriculture Sciences were identified based on analysis
of combined ITS, EF1-Î±, BT and CAL sequence data. The phylogenies
inferred from combined multi-locus analyses grouped the isolates from P.
persica into six distinct lineages with high branch support, which
corresponded to two previously described species and four novel species.
Diaporthe eres was the dominant species; D. mahothocarpus is reported
for the first time from Prunus persica. In addition, four novel
Diaporthe species were revealed and are introduced as new species in
this paper. Inoculations of all species were conducted on excised peach
shoots. All Diaporthe species isolated in this study caused gummosis in
excised peach shoots, whereas Diaporthe mahothocarpus was shown to be an
aggressive pathogen. This is the first detailed report of Diaporthe
species causing peach gummosis in China and provides details on
morphology, pathogenicity and molecular data.
